[COMPLEXITY]: Overly complex sentence structures may hinder smooth reading for some readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from historical analysis to 18th-century vignette (e.g., Admiral Keppel paragraph).
[ASSUMPTION]: Assumes reader familiarity with historical figures (e.g., Von Eicken, Sybel).

[SYNTAX]: Abrupt, unreferenced dialogue snippets disrupt sentence flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden shifts between historical and modern themes without transitional links.
[TRANSITION]: Unintegrated narrative quotes (e.g., "My own darling...") interrupt thematic coherence.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures may hinder readability.

[TRANSITION]: Minor abruptness in introducing historical quotes without contextual framing.

[SYNTAX]: Complex, lengthy sentences may impede smooth readability.
[LEXICON]: Archaisms and formal vocabulary (e.g., "leonine head," "sentimental antiquarianism") could challenge modern readers.

[CLARITY]: Abrupt, unexplained reference to "The Indian story of the Park."
[TRANSITION]: Slightly tangential digressions (e.g., portrait comparison, Ovid quote) while still serving the argument.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures with multiple embedded clauses (e.g., "Tennyson saw that the Victorian social order was breaking up; and with great prescience...").
[LEXICON]: Occasional archaic or less common vocabulary (e.g., "vulgarised," "cataract of ink").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt topic shifts (e.g., from Tennyson’s disillusionment to Victorian novels to Industrial Revolution critiques).
[TRANSITION]: Lack of explicit connections between ideas (e.g., transition from literature to imperialism lacks bridging phrases).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, lengthy sentences may impede smooth readability for some readers.

[TRANSITION]: Sudden shift from industrial woes to historical "twin peaks" comparison without explicit link.
[STRUCTURE]: Introduction of Europe’s primacy sacrifice feels somewhat disconnected from preceding themes.
